### Prerequisites

This text establishes a relationship with concepts previously studied. Thus, we recommend that the reader review the previous texts from the four chapters before proceeding

### Introduction

After four chapters dedicated to studying the different ways humanity developed counting methods—whether through addition or multiplication—we cannot claim the subject is exhausted. On many occasions, we perform sums and multiplications indirectly without even noticing.

With this in mind, reflect before proceeding:

Reflection 1: On the Texts

How do you believe addition and multiplication relate to the texts you read?

### An Overview

Whenever we read or write something, we are performing mathematical operations that, being so natural, go unnoticed. Let us explore this in more detail.

#### The Sum in Text

Often, because we are so focused on understanding what we're reading, we don't notice that we're summing letters to reach a final result: the comprehension of a word or text. One possible reason we don't observe this summation could be that we don't use the addition symbol (+) during reading.

#### Multiplication

When we combine letter by letter to write or read a word, we're also applying the multiplication table of 1 (<htcite0>). As with summation, we don't insert the multiplication symbol (×) in this interpretation, though it is implicit.

Multiplication also helps us navigate through text. As mentioned in the first text of Chapter 4, to multiply is to perform repeated addition of a quantity (<htcite1>). Since texts are organized in lines - sometimes called verses (<htcite2>)— when moving from one line to another, we can interpret this as performing multiplication. An example of text in verses is Gustavo Dourado's poem *LABUTA*, presented below (<htcite3>; <htcite4>):

• LABUTA
  •  
  • Trabalhador:
  • Trabalho-e-dor
  • Sangue, suor
  • A ganga bruta
  • A batalha cotidiana
  • Nossa dura labuta
  • Mudar o sistema
  • Só com muita luta

#### Plotting the Letter Count

In the last text of the previous chapter (<htcite0>), it was stated that when working with the real world, we cannot limit number multiplication to 10. In these first sections of this text, we already encounter a scenario that demonstrates the need for expansion. To count all the letters written so far, we cannot restrict our count to ten.

For example, let us plot the twelve symbols (11 letters and two points) present in the first verse of the poem *LABUTA* (<htcite1>; <htcite2>):
Chart 1: Letter Count in the First Verse. Chart created with Chart JS.
In addition to these examples, multiplication also appears implicitly in poems' syllables, as we will see in the next section.

### Poems

When writing a poem, the author may choose between free composition or adherence to a metrical structure (<htcite0>).

#### Defining Meter

If a specific meter is selected, each verse of the poem must contain the same number of metrical syllables. Note that metrical conventions vary across languages. For simplicity, this text adopts the Portuguese language’s definitions and examples. However, readers may consult the University of Pennsylvania (<htcite1>).

In Portuguese, metrical syllables are counted up to the last stressed syllable—the most emphatically pronounced syllable—rather than the total number of syllables in a verse (<htcite2>).

The poem *"Voltas"* consists of 5-syllable verses, known in Portuguese as *redondilhas menores* (<htcite3>). Below is the reproduced text (<htcite4>):

• Voltas
  •  
  • Da lindeza vossa,
  • Dama, quem a vê,
  • impossível é
  • que guardar-se possa.
  • Se faz tanta mossa
  • ver-vos um só dia,
  • quem se guardaria?
  •  
  • Milhor deve ser
  • neste aventurar,
  • ver, e não guardar,
  • que guardar de ver.
  • Ver, e defender,
  • muito bom seria;
  • mas... quem poderia?

#### The Multiplication Table of *Voltas*

Before analyzing the poem’s syllables, let us highlight key features:

- Each verse (line) of 'Voltas' contains exactly 5 Portuguese metrical syllables.
- Each strophe—a group of verses separated by empty lines (<htcite0>)—comprises 7 verses.
- The poem contains two strophes.

Given this structure, the total metrical syllables can be calculated through different mathematical operations:

- **Sum of individual syllables**: <math> <munderover> <mo>∑</mo> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>70</mn></mrow> </munderover> <mi>1</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>1 × (70)</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>70</mi></math>
- **Sum per strophe**: <math> <munderover> <mo>∑</mo> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>7</mn></mrow> </munderover> <mi>5</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>7 × (5)</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>35</mi></math>. With two strophes: 35 + 35 = 2 × (35) = 70
- **Sum across all verses**: <math> <munderover> <mo>∑</mo> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>14</mn></mrow> </munderover> <mi>5</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>14 × (5)</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>70</mi></math>. (*This last method will be explored in detail elsewhere.*)

#### Verse Chart

Since the number of metrical syllables is constant for all verses, a graphical representation would show a flat line on the vertical axis:

exercise_v2.question: Textos jamais se misturam com a matemática?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: A pergunta simplesmente não faz sentido. A matemática está presente em qualquer área de nossa vida, mas muita das vezes aparece de maneira implícita.

exercise_v2.question: A contagem de sílabas métricas podem ser feita por multiplicação?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Ao contarmos as sílabas métricas de um verso, utilizamos a tabuada de 1. Se o poema segue uma única métrica em todos os versos, então podemos multiplicar o total de versos pela quantidade de sílabas métricas em um texto.
